elements.content: The synthesis and X-ray crystallographic structure of a 3-D brick-wall coordination polymer of TMEDA-supported dimeric 2,3-dialkyl-1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene are reported. TMEDAs behave as bridging coordinating ligands rather than intramolecular chelating ligands. The Li4-tetrahedron core was stable toward the deaggregation of TMEDA because of the small steric hindrance on the butadiene skeleton.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis and X-ray crystallographic structure of a 3-D brick-wall coordination polymer of TMEDA-supported dimeric 2,3-dialkyl-1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene are reported. TMEDAs behave as bridging coordinating ligands rather than intramolecular chelating ligands. The Li4-tetrahedron core was stable toward the deaggregation of TMEDA because of the small steric hindrance on the butadiene skeleton.

elements.content: The study on structures of organolithium compounds is of fundamental interest because they are very important in both organometallic chemistry and synthetic chemistry. In general, organolithium compounds exist in a variety of aggregation states, including monomers, oligomers, and polymers. For example, n-BuLi and EtLi exist as hexamers and tetramers in the solid state, respectively, while MeLi forms a 3-D polymeric network in which (MeLi)4 tetrahedra are linked to each other through Li3–Me–Li long-range interactions. Different types of ligands, including coordinating solvent molecules such as tetrahydrofuran (THF) and chelating ligands such as N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA), are often used to deaggregate the organolithium oligomers or polymers. In fact, in combination with chelating or bridging ligands, organolithium compounds may form a variety of architectures such as a 1-D polymeric chain, a 3-D network or a porous cage-shaped structure. For examples, as bridging ligands, TMEDAs connect (MeLi)4 tetrahedra to form the 3-D network [(MeLi)4(TMEDA)2] n without deaggregation of the (MeLi)4 tetrahedra; as chelating ligands, TMEDAs deaggregate organodilithium dimer 1 to form and stabilize the monomer [1-TMEDA] (Scheme ). Thus, the ligands usually play key roles in modulating the structures and reactivities of organolithium reagents.
elements.clean_text: The study on structures of organolithium compounds is of fundamental interest because they are very important in both organometallic chemistry and synthetic chemistry. In general, organolithium compounds exist in a variety of aggregation states, including monomers, oligomers, and polymers. For example, n-BuLi and EtLi exist as hexamers and tetramers in the solid state, respectively, while MeLi forms a 3-D polymeric network in which (MeLi)4 tetrahedra are linked to each other through Li3-Me-Li long-range interactions. Different types of ligands, including coordinating solvent molecules such as tetrahydrofuran (THF) and chelating ligands such as N,N,N',N'-tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA), are often used to deaggregate the organolithium oligomers or polymers. In fact, in combination with chelating or bridging ligands, organolithium compounds may form a variety of architectures such as a 1-D polymeric chain, a 3-D network or a porous cage-shaped structure. For examples, as bridging ligands, TMEDAs connect (MeLi)4 tetrahedra to form the 3-D network [(MeLi)4(TMEDA)2] n  without deaggregation of the (MeLi)4 tetrahedra; as chelating ligands, TMEDAs deaggregate organodilithium dimer 1 to form and stabilize the monomer [1-TMEDA] (Scheme ). Thus, the ligands usually play key roles in modulating the structures and reactivities of organolithium reagents.

elements.clean_text: 1  Selected Well-Defined Organodilithium Compounds

elements.content: We have been working on the structures and reaction chemistry of 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadienes. The substitution pattern on the butadienyl skeleton remarkably affects the structure of these dilithio compounds. In 2010, we reported the X-ray crystallographic structures of the trimeric all-alkyl-substituted 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene 2 with a Li6 pseudooctahedron and dimeric Me3Si-substituted 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadienes 1 and 3 with Li4 tetrahedra. We envisioned that the aggregation states of these organodilithium reagents depend on both the steric effects of substituents on the butadiene skeleton and the ligands.
elements.clean_text: We have been working on the structures and reaction chemistry of 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadienes. The substitution pattern on the butadienyl skeleton remarkably affects the structure of these dilithio compounds. In 2010, we reported the X-ray crystallographic structures of the trimeric all-alkyl-substituted 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene 2 with a Li6 pseudooctahedron and dimeric Me3Si-substituted 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadienes 1 and 3 with Li4 tetrahedra. We envisioned that the aggregation states of these organodilithium reagents depend on both the steric effects of substituents on the butadiene skeleton and the ligands.

elements.content: In this work, we report the synthesis and structure of a 3-D brick-wall coordination polymer of TMEDA-supported dimeric, less bulky 2,3-dialkyl-1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene. TMEDAs behave as bridging coordinating ligands rather than intramolecular chelating ligands and thus construct a 3-D polymeric network by bridging the Li4 tetrahedra, which has been confirmed by X-ray analysis. The TMEDA-chelated monomer 4 as a deaggregation product was not formed.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we report the synthesis and structure of a 3-D brick-wall coordination polymer of TMEDA-supported dimeric, less bulky 2,3-dialkyl-1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene. TMEDAs behave as bridging coordinating ligands rather than intramolecular chelating ligands and thus construct a 3-D polymeric network by bridging the Li4 tetrahedra, which has been confirmed by X-ray analysis. The TMEDA-chelated monomer 4 as a deaggregation product was not formed.

elements.content: 2,3-Dibutyl-1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene (5) in a solution of diethyl ether was generated in situ from its corresponding 1,4-diiodo-1,3-butadiene and t-BuLi at −78 °C for 1 h (Scheme ). The salt-free 5 was obtained in 72% isolated yield by extraction of the in situ generated 5 with hexane and recrystallization in hexane after filtration of LiI. The α-carbon atom on the butadiene skeleton showed a broad singlet at 167.84 ppm in the 13C NMR spectrum in C4D8O, probably because of strong interaction of the α-carbon atom with two Li atoms. The β-carbon atom on the butadiene skeleton clearly displayed a sharp singlet at 161.49 ppm. No coordinating ligand or solvent molecule was found according to the 1H and 13C NMR spectra of 5 in C6D6.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

2,3-Dibutyl-1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene (5) in a solution of diethyl ether was generated in situ from its corresponding 1,4-diiodo-1,3-butadiene and t-BuLi at -78 °C for 1 h (Scheme ). The salt-free 5 was obtained in 72% isolated yield by extraction of the in situ generated 5 with hexane and recrystallization in hexane after filtration of LiI. The α-carbon atom on the butadiene skeleton showed a broad singlet at 167.84 ppm in the 13C NMR spectrum in C4D8O, probably because of strong interaction of the α-carbon atom with two Li atoms. The β-carbon atom on the butadiene skeleton clearly displayed a sharp singlet at 161.49 ppm. No coordinating ligand or solvent molecule was found according to the 1H and 13C NMR spectra of 5 in C6D6.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch2" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<caption>
<title>Preparation of [<bold>5</bold>-THF]</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr2" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="om-2013-00531h_0006.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 2  Preparation of [5-THF]

elements.content: Single crystals of [5-THF] suitable for X-ray structural analysis were grown in hexane/THF at −20 °C. The complex [5-THF] crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The structure of [5-THF] clearly shows a pseudo-D 2-symmetrical dimeric structure featuring a Li4 tetrahedron and double dilithium bridges (Figure ), which is similar to our reported dimeric structures of organodilithium reagents 1 and 3. the expected higher aggregation state did not form. The bond lengths of C(1)–Li(1) and C(4)–Li(1) (2.160(7)–2.191(8) Å) are comparable with those reported for the lithium bridges observed in 2 (average 2.13 Å) and 3 (average 2.19 Å), suggesting the existence of a lithium bridge in a butadiene unit. The environments of the other lithium atoms are similar to that of Li(1). The Li–Li distance in the same butadiene unit is 2.817(9) Å, which is comparable with those in [1-TMEDA] (2.64 Å), 2 (average 2.62 Å), and 3 (average 2.84 Å). Each Li atom is coordinated by one THF ligand, one η2-coordinated butadiene moiety, and one weakly η1 coordinated terminal carbon atom of the other butadiene moiety. This coordination environment of [5-THF] is different from that of our previously reported trimeric all-alkyl-substituted dilithium compound 2 and dimeric Me3Si-substituted dilithium compounds 1 and 3. In the crystal structures of 1 and 2, no external ligand is coordinated to the Li atom, while in the crystal structure of 3, THF ligands are only coordinated to the less-hindered, α-phenyl-substituted Li atom. We suggest that the Li atom in 5 is much less hindered and more easily accepts THF coordination because of no substituent on the 1,4-position of the butadiene skeleton. This result again suggests that the substitution pattern and steric hindrance on the butadienyl skeleton have a strong effect on the aggregation states and coordination environment of Li atoms in organodilithium compounds.

The structure of [5-THF] clearly shows a pseudo-D 2-symmetrical dimeric structure featuring a Li4 tetrahedron and double dilithium bridges (Figure ), which is similar to our reported dimeric structures of organodilithium reagents 1 and 3. the expected higher aggregation state did not form. The bond lengths of C(1)-Li(1) and C(4)-Li(1) (2.160(7)-2.191(8) Å) are comparable with those reported for the lithium bridges observed in 2 (average 2.13 Å) and 3 (average 2.19 Å), suggesting the existence of a lithium bridge in a butadiene unit. The environments of the other lithium atoms are similar to that of Li(1). The Li-Li distance in the same butadiene unit is 2.817(9) Å, which is comparable with those in [1-TMEDA] (2.64 Å), 2 (average 2.62 Å), and 3 (average 2.84 Å). Each Li atom is coordinated by one THF ligand, one η2-coordinated butadiene moiety, and one weakly η1 coordinated terminal carbon atom of the other butadiene moiety. This coordination environment of [5-THF] is different from that of our previously reported trimeric all-alkyl-substituted dilithium compound 2 and dimeric Me3Si-substituted dilithium compounds 1 and 3. In the crystal structures of 1 and 2, no external ligand is coordinated to the Li atom, while in the crystal structure of 3, THF ligands are only coordinated to the less-hindered, α-phenyl-substituted Li atom. We suggest that the Li atom in 5 is much less hindered and more easily accepts THF coordination because of no substituent on the 1,4-position of the butadiene skeleton. This result again suggests that the substitution pattern and steric hindrance on the butadienyl skeleton have a strong effect on the aggregation states and coordination environment of Li atoms in organodilithium compounds.

elements.content: ORTEP drawing of [5-THF] with 30% thermal ellipsoids. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Selected bond lengths (Å): C(1)–C(2) = 1.348(5), C(2)–C(3) = 1.518(5), C(3)–C(4) = 1.352(5), C(1)–Li(1) = 2.160(7), C(1)–Li(2) = 2.177(8), C(4)–Li(1) = 2.191(8), C(4)–Li(2) = 2.160(8), C(1)–Li(1′) = 2.244(7), C(4)–Li(2′) = 2.219(7). Symmetry-equivalent atoms (denoted with ′) are given by the following: −x, y, −z + 1/2; x + 1/2, y + 1/2, z; −x + 1/2, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2.
elements.clean_text: 1  ORTEP drawing of [5-THF] with 30% thermal ellipsoids. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Selected bond lengths (Å): C(1)-C(2) = 1.348(5), C(2)-C(3) = 1.518(5), C(3)-C(4) = 1.352(5), C(1)-Li(1) = 2.160(7), C(1)-Li(2) = 2.177(8), C(4)-Li(1) = 2.191(8), C(4)-Li(2) = 2.160(8), C(1)-Li(1') = 2.244(7), C(4)-Li(2') = 2.219(7). Symmetry-equivalent atoms (denoted with ') are given by the following: -x, y, -z + 1/2; x + 1/2, y + 1/2, z; -x + 1/2, y + 1/2, -z + 1/2.

elements.content: We envisioned that TMEDA as a chelating ligand might be able to deaggregate 5 and thus form the monomeric structure. Recrystallization of 5 in hexane/diethyl ether/TMEDA solution afforded colorless crystals of [5-TMEDA] (Scheme ). The complex [5-TMEDA] crystallized in the tetragonal space group I41/a. However, to our surprise, X-ray structural analysis did not give the expected monomeric structure but revealed the infinite 3-D brick-wall polymeric structure [(5)2(TMEDA)2] n comprised of dimeric 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene cores and TMEDA bridges. The asymmetric unit contains only half of the TMEDA and half of the 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene, which indicates a D 2-symmetrical structure. The geometric parameters of the Li4-tetrahedron cores of [5-TMEDA] are similar to those of [5-THF]. The C(5)–Li(1) bond length (2.158(4) Å) is close to that in [5-THF] (average 2.17 Å), while the Li–Li distance in the same butadiene unit is 2.840(7) Å, also comparable with that observed in [5-THF] (2.819(8) Å). Each Li atom is coordinated by only one N atom of the TMEDA ligand, one η2-coordinated butadiene moiety, and one weakly η1 coordinated terminal carbon atom of the other butadiene moiety. The two N atoms of each TMEDA are connected to two Li atoms belonging to two different Li4 cores (Figure ). TMEDA herein acted as a bridging ligand instead of a chelating ligand. As shown in Figure and Scheme , in a monolayer of the 3-D brick-wall polymeric structure of [5-TMEDA], six Li4 cores and six TMEDA bridges comprise a chairlike macrocyclic unit. In a view along the c axis the topological structure of the chairlike unit transforms into a rectangle, and six Li4 cores are positioned on four corners and two midpoints of the long side of the rectangular brick. The rectangular bricks extend to form 2-D brick-wall monolayers viewed along the c axis in crystalline [5-TMEDA] via N–Li coordination. The brick-wall monolayers are linked by TMEDA molecules to form the 3-D network, also forming chairlike Li4-TMEDA macrocycles.
elements.clean_text: We envisioned that TMEDA as a chelating ligand might be able to deaggregate 5 and thus form the monomeric structure. Recrystallization of 5 in hexane/diethyl ether/TMEDA solution afforded colorless crystals of [5-TMEDA] (Scheme ). The complex [5-TMEDA] crystallized in the tetragonal space group I41/a. However, to our surprise, X-ray structural analysis did not give the expected monomeric structure but revealed the infinite 3-D brick-wall polymeric structure [(5)2(TMEDA)2] n  comprised of dimeric 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene cores and TMEDA bridges. The asymmetric unit contains only half of the TMEDA and half of the 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene, which indicates a D 2-symmetrical structure. The geometric parameters of the Li4-tetrahedron cores of [5-TMEDA] are similar to those of [5-THF]. The C(5)-Li(1) bond length (2.158(4) Å) is close to that in [5-THF] (average 2.17 Å), while the Li-Li distance in the same butadiene unit is 2.840(7) Å, also comparable with that observed in [5-THF] (2.819(8) Å). Each Li atom is coordinated by only one N atom of the TMEDA ligand, one η2-coordinated butadiene moiety, and one weakly η1 coordinated terminal carbon atom of the other butadiene moiety. The two N atoms of each TMEDA are connected to two Li atoms belonging to two different Li4 cores (Figure ). TMEDA herein acted as a bridging ligand instead of a chelating ligand. As shown in Figure  and Scheme , in a monolayer of the 3-D brick-wall polymeric structure of [5-TMEDA], six Li4 cores and six TMEDA bridges comprise a chairlike macrocyclic unit. In a view along the c axis the topological structure of the chairlike unit transforms into a rectangle, and six Li4 cores are positioned on four corners and two midpoints of the long side of the rectangular brick. The rectangular bricks extend to form 2-D brick-wall monolayers viewed along the c axis in crystalline [5-TMEDA] via N-Li coordination. The brick-wall monolayers are linked by TMEDA molecules to form the 3-D network, also forming chairlike Li4-TMEDA macrocycles.

Selected bond lengths (Å): C(4)–C(4a) = 1.534(5), C(4)–C(5) = 1.356(4), C(5)–Li(1) = 2.158(4), C(5)–Li(1a) = 2.180(4), C(5)–Li(1′) = 2.237(5). Color scheme: C, gray; N, blue; Li, dark red. Symmetry-equivalent atoms (denoted with ') are given by the following : -x + 1/2, -y, z + 1/2; -y + 3/4, x + 1/4, z + 1/4; y + 3/4, -x + 3/4, z + 3/4; x + 1/2, y + 1/2, z + 1/2; -x + 1, -y + 1/2, z + 1; -y + 5/4, x + 3/4, z + 3/4; y + 5/4, -x + 5/4, z + 5/4.

Hydrogen atoms, butyls, butadiene skeletons, and methyls on TMEDAs are omitted for clarity. Color scheme: C, gray; N, blue; Li, dark red.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Two-dimensional brick-wall motif in crystalline [5-TMEDA] via N-Li coordination and (b) layer-by-layer stacked network in crystalline [5-TMEDA]. Hydrogen atoms, butyls, butadiene skeletons, and methyls on TMEDAs are omitted for clarity. Color scheme: C, gray; N, blue; Li, dark red.

elements.content: As far as we are aware, the bridging ligand connected 3-D brick-wall network has not been reported previously in the solid structure of organodilithium compounds. For organomonolithium reagents, a few of them were found to possess similar 3-D networks, such as [(MeLi)4(TMEDA)2] n , [(n-BuLi)4(TMEDA)2] n , and [(n-BuLi)4(DME)4] n , in which TMEDA or 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) ligands each linked two adjacent (RLi)4 tetrahedra. We suggest that the Li4-tetrahedron core was stable enough toward the deaggregation of TMEDA because of the smaller steric hindrance of the substitution pattern on the butadiene skeleton.
elements.clean_text: As far as we are aware, the bridging ligand connected 3-D brick-wall network has not been reported previously in the solid structure of organodilithium compounds. For organomonolithium reagents, a few of them were found to possess similar 3-D networks, such as [(MeLi)4(TMEDA)2] n , [(n-BuLi)4(TMEDA)2] n , and [(n-BuLi)4(DME)4] n , in which TMEDA or 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) ligands each linked two adjacent (RLi)4 tetrahedra. We suggest that the Li4-tetrahedron core was stable enough toward the deaggregation of TMEDA because of the smaller steric hindrance of the substitution pattern on the butadiene skeleton.

elements.content: In summary, we have reported the synthesis and X-ray crystallographic structure of a 3-D brick-wall coordination polymer of TMEDA-supported 2,3-dibutyl-1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene dimer. The use of TMEDA as a bridging ligand rather than a chelating ligand is the key in forming the 3-D brick-wall polymeric network.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have reported the synthesis and X-ray crystallographic structure of a 3-D brick-wall coordination polymer of TMEDA-supported 2,3-dibutyl-1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadiene dimer. The use of TMEDA as a bridging ligand rather than a chelating ligand is the key in forming the 3-D brick-wall polymeric network.

elements.content: All reactions were conducted under a slightly positive pressure of dry nitrogen using standard Schlenk line techniques or under a nitrogen atmosphere in a Mikrouna Super (1220/750) glovebox. The nitrogen in the glovebox was constantly circulated through a copper/molecular sieves catalyst unit. The oxygen and moisture concentrations in the glovebox atmosphere were monitored by an O2/H2O Combi-Analyzer to ensure both were always below 1 ppm. Unless otherwise noted, all starting materials were commercially available and were used without further purification. Solvents were purified by an Mbraun SPS-800 Solvent Purification System and dried over fresh Na chips in the glovebox. 1,4-Iodo-1,3-butadiene was synthesized by the reported procedure.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Method

All reactions were conducted under a slightly positive pressure of dry nitrogen using standard Schlenk line techniques or under a nitrogen atmosphere in a Mikrouna Super (1220/750) glovebox. The nitrogen in the glovebox was constantly circulated through a copper/molecular sieves catalyst unit. The oxygen and moisture concentrations in the glovebox atmosphere were monitored by an O2/H2O Combi-Analyzer to ensure both were always below 1 ppm. Unless otherwise noted, all starting materials were commercially available and were used without further purification. Solvents were purified by an Mbraun SPS-800 Solvent Purification System and dried over fresh Na chips in the glovebox. 1,4-Iodo-1,3-butadiene was synthesized by the reported procedure.

elements.content: Organometallic samples for NMR spectroscopic measurements were prepared in the glovebox by use of J. Young valve NMR tubes (Wilmad 528-JY). 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL-AL300 spectrometer (FT, 300 MHz for 1H; 75 MHz for 13C) at room temperature, unless otherwise noted.
elements.clean_text: Organometallic samples for NMR spectroscopic measurements were prepared in the glovebox by use of J. Young valve NMR tubes (Wilmad 528-JY). 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a JEOL-AL300 spectrometer (FT, 300 MHz for 1H; 75 MHz for 13C) at room temperature, unless otherwise noted.

elements.content: t-BuLi (2.0 mmol, 1.5 M in pentane) was added dropwise at −78 °C to a stirred solution of 1,4-iodo-1,3-butadiene (0.5 mmol) in Et2O (5 mL). After it was stirred at −78 °C for 1 h, the reaction mixture was warmed to room temperature. The solvents were removed under vacuum in the glovebox, and the residue was dissolved in hexane (10 mL) and filtered. This step may need to be repeated several times until the residue powder after evaporation can be totally dissolved in n-hexane to form a clear solution. The powders thus obtained as salt -free 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadienes 5 are pure enough for NMR analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Typical Procedure for the Preparation of 1,4-Dilithio-1,3-butadiene

 t-BuLi (2.0 mmol, 1.5 M in pentane) was added dropwise at -78 °C to a stirred solution of 1,4-iodo-1,3-butadiene (0.5 mmol) in Et2O (5 mL). After it was stirred at -78 °C for 1 h, the reaction mixture was warmed to room temperature. The solvents were removed under vacuum in the glovebox, and the residue was dissolved in hexane (10 mL) and filtered. This step may need to be repeated several times until the residue powder after evaporation can be totally dissolved in n-hexane to form a clear solution. The powders thus obtained as salt -free 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadienes 5 are pure enough for NMR analysis.

elements.content: Complex 5: light orange powder, isolated yield 72% (256 mg); 1H NMR (300 MHz, C4D8O, Me4Si) δ 0.83 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 12H, CH3), 1.12–1.46 (m, 16H, CH2), 2.26 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 8H, CH2), 6.26 (s, 4H, CH); 13C NMR (75 MHz, C4D8O, Me4Si) 13.84 (4 CH3), 23.27 (4 CH2), 33.97 (4 CH2), 40.73 (4 CH2), 161.49 (4 quart C), 167.84 (br, 4 C–Li). Recrystallization of 5 in hexane/THF (1/1) at −20 °C gave crystals of [5-THF] suitable for X-ray analysis. Recrystallization of 5 in hexane/Et2O/TMEDA (1/1/0.1) at room temperature gave crystals of [5-TMEDA] suitable for X-ray analysis.
elements.clean_text: Complex 5: light orange powder, isolated yield 72% (256 mg); 1H NMR (300 MHz, C4D8O, Me4Si) δ 0.83 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 12H, CH3), 1.12-1.46 (m, 16H, CH2), 2.26 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 8H, CH2), 6.26 (s, 4H, CH); 13C NMR (75 MHz, C4D8O, Me4Si) 13.84 (4 CH3), 23.27 (4 CH2), 33.97 (4 CH2), 40.73 (4 CH2), 161.49 (4 quart C), 167.84 (br, 4 C-Li). Recrystallization of 5 in hexane/THF (1/1) at -20 °C gave crystals of [5-THF] suitable for X-ray analysis. Recrystallization of 5 in hexane/Et2O/TMEDA (1/1/0.1) at room temperature gave crystals of [5-TMEDA] suitable for X-ray analysis.

elements.content: Complex [5-TMEDA]: colorless crystal; 1H NMR (300 MHz, C6D6 + C4D8O, Me4Si) δ 0.95 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 12H, CH3), 1.45–1.49 (m, 8H, CH2), 1.67–1.72 (m, 8H, CH2), 2.04 (s, 12H, CH3), 2.06 (s, 12H, CH3), 2.17 (s, 4H, CH2), 2.19 (s, 4H, CH2), 2.60 (m, 8H, CH2), 6.63 (s, 4H, CH); 13C NMR (75 MHz, C6D6 + C4D8O, Me4Si) δ 14.12 (4 CH3), 23.38 (4 CH2), 34.10 (4 CH2), 40.87 (4 CH2), 45.61 (4 CH2), 57.43 (8 CH3), 161.80 (4 quart C), 168.14 (br, 4 C–Li).

Crystals for X-ray analyses of the compounds were obtained as described above. The crystals were manipulated in the glovebox and were sealed in thin-walled glass capillaries. Data collections were performed on a Rigaku CCD Saturn 724 diffractometer, using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The determination of crystal class and unit cell parameters was carried out by the CrystalClear (Rigaku Inc., 2007) program package. The raw frame data were processed using Crystal Structure (Rigaku/MSC 2000) to yield the reflection data file. These structures were solved by use of the SHELXTL program. Refinement was performed on F 2 anisotropically for all the non-hydrogen atoms by the full-matrix least-squares method. The hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated positions and were included in the structure calculation without further refinement of the parameters. Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication nos. CCDC- ([5-THF]) and CCDC- ([5-TMEDA]). These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Studies

Crystals for X-ray analyses of the compounds were obtained as described above. The crystals were manipulated in the glovebox and were sealed in thin-walled glass capillaries. Data collections were performed on a Rigaku CCD Saturn 724 diffractometer, using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The determination of crystal class and unit cell parameters was carried out by the CrystalClear (Rigaku Inc., 2007) program package. The raw frame data were processed using Crystal Structure (Rigaku/MSC 2000) to yield the reflection data file. These structures were solved by use of the SHELXTL program. Refinement was performed on F 2 anisotropically for all the non-hydrogen atoms by the full-matrix least-squares method. The hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated positions and were included in the structure calculation without further refinement of the parameters. Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication nos. CCDC- ([5-THF]) and CCDC- ([5-TMEDA]). These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

cln_elements.content: t-BuLi (2.0 mmol, 1.5 M in pentane) was added dropwise at −78 °C to a stirred solution of 1,4-iodo-1,3-butadiene (0.5 mmol) in Et2O (5 mL). After it was stirred at −78 °C for 1 h, the reaction mixture was warmed to room temperature. The solvents were removed under vacuum in the glovebox, and the residue was dissolved in hexane (10 mL) and filtered. This step may need to be repeated several times until the residue powder after evaporation can be totally dissolved in n-hexane to form a clear solution. The powders thus obtained as salt -free 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadienes 5 are pure enough for NMR analysis.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Typical Procedure for the Preparation of 1,4-Dilithio-1,3-butadiene

 t-BuLi (2.0 mmol, 1.5 M in pentane) was added dropwise at -78 °C to a stirred solution of 1,4-iodo-1,3-butadiene (0.5 mmol) in Et2O (5 mL). After it was stirred at -78 °C for 1 h, the reaction mixture was warmed to room temperature. The solvents were removed under vacuum in the glovebox, and the residue was dissolved in hexane (10 mL) and filtered. This step may need to be repeated several times until the residue powder after evaporation can be totally dissolved in n-hexane to form a clear solution. The powders thus obtained as salt -free 1,4-dilithio-1,3-butadienes 5 are pure enough for NMR analysis.

cln_elements.content:
Complex 5: light orange powder, isolated yield 72% (256 mg); 1H NMR (300 MHz, C4D8O, Me4Si) δ 0.83 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 12H, CH3), 1.12–1.46 (m, 16H, CH2), 2.26 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 8H, CH2), 6.26 (s, 4H, CH); 13C NMR (75 MHz, C4D8O, Me4Si) 13.84 (4 CH3), 23.27 (4 CH2), 33.97 (4 CH2), 40.73 (4 CH2), 161.49 (4 quart C), 167.84 (br, 4 C–Li). Recrystallization of 5 in hexane/THF (1/1) at −20 °C gave crystals of [5-THF] suitable for X-ray analysis. Recrystallization of 5 in hexane/Et2O/TMEDA (1/1/0.1) at room temperature gave crystals of [5-TMEDA] suitable for X-ray analysis.
